column4: OK, so sudo chmod appeared to work, but when I look at the properties of the folder they are the same...? what gives?

o+rX should work, though.  Out of curiousity try sudo chmod 705 Music
You cannot change permissions of an ntfs volume.
Since they are not unix permissions, what you want to do it change how you mount it.
Show me the command you used to mount it.
I happen to have an NTFS volume from another system, let me take a peek.
Can you show me (via pastebin) the output of 'mount' in a terminal?
Mine defaulted to using ntfs-3g with 'allow_other' option
No problem, just type 'mount' to get a snapshot of what is currently mounted.
Really just the line with Music (or whatever) is fine.
So basically, because it's using fuse/ntfs-3g the filesystem permissions you see are just for compatability.
For example, I am able to read/write to my ntfs volume as my user, even though they all show rwx------ in ls -l.
There are so many layers of abstractions here, you're trying to mount an NTFS volume and share it via Samba? (to Windows systems)
So, how are you trying to share it.  Right click > 'Sharing Options'?
